Dilrabohon is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married to a builder; his monthly salary is 3000 soms. Together they are bringing up a son, who is preschool age and goes to a kindergarten. The family owns 0.5 hectares of land and they use it to cultivate cotton.  Selling the cotton on the market Dilrabohon earns an additional 5000 soms per month. 

She applied for the loan because she needs additional funds to purchase mineral fertilizers for cultivating cotton. In the future she plans to purchase cattle in order to resell them at a higher price after being fattened. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers.

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben is a 29-year-old married man. He is in the transport sector in Magongo, Mombasa. He also sells GNLD supplement products. His business has been in operation for one year and has been a success. 

He has been a KADET LTD client and this marks his fourth borrowing to finance his business. With this loan, he plans to purchase more stock of GNLD supplement products.

The anticipated profits will be used to repay back the loan and to gradually expand his business.

Reuben's dream is to become prosperous and to be able to sustain his family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of GNLD supplement products

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is 43 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has four children. Two of her children are currently in school.  

Prossy has a business of selling timber that is used for building houses. She has had this business for less than one year. She also has a second business of rental houses.  

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase timber for building houses. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Prossy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  

In the future, Prossy hopes to expand her business into a bigger one.

loans.use: to purchase timber.

loans.name: Khayolbi

texts.ru: Хаёлби проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 46 лет. Она замужем. У нее трое детей. Она имеет среднее образование. Хаёлби предоставляет услугу. У нее имеется столовая на рынке "Саховат", где она работает поваром. В этой области Хаёлби работает уже четыре года. Она берет кредит для приобретения камфорной плитки и духовки.
texts.en: Khayolbi lives in the city of Kulob.  She is 46 years old, married, and has three children.  She has a secondary education.  Khayolbi offers a service.  She has a cafe in the Sakhovat market where she works as a cook.  Khayolbi has been doing this for four years.  She is taking out a loan to buy ovens and portable stoves.

loans.use: to buy ovens and portable stoves.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira is the leader of this group. She is 47 and married to a welder. Together with her husband she has raised two sons and a daughter. The first son works in construction, the second goes to school and the daughter is at university.

In order to earn money to meet the family’s daily needs, Gulmira sells flour. With her profits she has been able to provide her children with a good education. She also purchased an old Soviet Moskvich car for the family.

Gulmira has applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to repair her house. In the future she wants to expand her flour business.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Victoria Lili

texts.es:
La Sra. Victoria pertenece al Banco Comunal “Esmeralda”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene  38 años y 02 hijos estudiantes de  nivel  primario y secundario de 14 y 09 años de edad. Anteriormente trabajó ejerciendo su carrera de técnica en construcción civil, pero desde que tuvo sus hijos se dedicó a su familia, esto implicó buscar sus propios ingresos económicos y decidió vender comida con entrega a domicilio; con el apoyo de su pareja pudo construir su casa, donde actualmente vende su comidas tipo menú (por las mañanas), asados y parrillas (por las noches), su clientela es el público en general, cuenta con una ayudante de cocina. Sus clientes la prefieren por su sazón y buen trato que les brinda.
Con este préstamo de S/. 3000.00 comprará productos al por mayor e ingredientes para la preparación de su comida como arroz y azúcar por sacos, aceite en litros, menestras de diversas variedades, carne de vacuno de aves, de porcino, pescados y mariscos de esa manera atender a sus clientes como ellos se merecen. Victoria es una mujer trabajadora y creativa,  su sueño es ampliar su negocio de venta de menú y que le permita crecer en forma independiente, está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindar la oportunidad de cumplir sus sueños.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the communal bank "Esmeralda" of the district of Tarapoto, located in the province and department of San Martin. She is married common-law, 38 years old, and she has 2 children. They are in primary school and high school and they are 9 and 14 years of age. Previously she practiced her career as a civil construction technician but since she had her children she decided to dedicate herself to her family. This implied that she needed to seek out a way to earn her own income and she decided to start delivering prepared foods. With the help of her partner she was able to build a house of her own, and it is where she currently sells prepared foods a la carte (in the mornings) and roasted and grilled foods (in the evenings). Her clientele is the general public and she has a hired cook. Her clients prefer her business for her recipes and for the good customer service provided.

With this loan, amounting to S/. 3000 nuevos soles, she will purchase products in wholesale and ingredients she needs to prepare foods, such as sacks of rice and sugar, liters of cooking oil, various types of soups, poultry, beef, and pork meat, fish and seafood. This way she will be able to attend her clients as they deserve. Victoria is a hardworking and creative woman and her dream is to expand her a la carte business. This will help her become independent. She is very thankful to the Manuela Ramos movement (Kiva Field Partner) for giving her opportunity of achieving her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as rice, sugar, fish, and seafood.

loans.name: Mehriniso

texts.ru: Мехринисо проживает в районе Дангара. Ей 46 лет. Она замужем. У нее четверо детей. Ее старший сын работает, а трое других учатся в школе. Сама Мехринисо представляет услугу. Она у себя дома занимается шитьем. Она шьет национальные платья. Этим видом деятельности занимается три года. Кредит берет для приобретения тканей, чтобы сшить платья для продажи.
texts.en: Mehriniso lives in the Dangara district.  She is 46 years old, married and has four children.  Her oldest son works, and the three others attend school.  Mehriniso provides a service of sewing national dresses at home.  She has been involved in this business for three years.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabrics in order to sew dresses for sale.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en: Luzviminda is 55 years old and married with 9 children. She works in the agricultural business farming vegetables in the Philippines. Luzviminda requested a loan of PHP 10,000 from Kiva's partner, NWTF, to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. Luzviminda has been farming vegetables for 6 years now, and has borrowed 2 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. Luzviminda would like to save enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Moisari

texts.en:
Moisari is 28 years old. He is married and a father of one child. He is a farmer and he has been doing this for the last five years. His farm is in a productive area that has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET LTD through KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, and he is planning to use the money to prepare his wheat farm. He paid his previous loans successfully. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to increase his wheat production and educate his children. 

His hope and dream is to buy a bigger piece of land and become a large-scale farmer. Moisari is a young and energetic man who can do more if supported financially

loans.use: to prepare his wheat farming

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Mr. Kang is one of the villagers of Kompong Speu province who has been engaged in the agricultural business since 1979. He would like to expand his farming business. However, due to the lack of capital to buy cows for plowing, Kang could not run his business operation well. Therefore, Mr. Kang would like to request a loan to buy cows for plowing the rice crop as well as other crops. With Kiva’s loan, Mr. Kang hopes that he’ll able to develop agriculture and make more income. Mr. Kang lives together with his wife and three daughters who are now working as garment factory workers in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows for plowing the rice crop as well as other crops.

loans.name: Constantina

texts.es: La señora Constantina es una mujer dedicada al hogar y al bienestar de sus hijos. La casa donde actualmente vive es de interés social que compro su esposo, con el fin de no pagar renta y tener su propio patrimonio. La casa es muy pequeña por tal motivo Constantina quiere que se construya un cuarto en la parte de enfrente para que viva mas cómoda la familia.  Para que el cuarto se construya se necesita comprar material de construcción como, arena, varilla, cemento y pagar mano de obra.
texts.en: Constantina is a woman who is dedicated to her home and to the well-being of her children. The house where she now lives is a social interest house that her husband bought so they wouldn’t have to pay rent and would have their own assets. The house is very small, which is why Constantina needs to build a room in the front part of the house, so that the family can live more comfortably. In order to build the room, she needs to buy construction materials, such as sand, rebar, and cement and pay for labor.

loans.use: to buy construction materials to build a room

loans.name: Renovación Group

texts.es:
El grupo Renovación está conformado por tres personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras una de ellas es Jenny quien se dedica al comercio de ropa y prendas. Este negocio lo inicio hace 10 años con unos ahorros luego como vio que necesitaba más inversión empezó a prestar en Adim. En la actualidad cuenta con tres trabajadores quienes distribuyen la mercadería.
Ella invertirá el crédito en mercadería en especial ropa por la temporada.
Las otras integrantes son Magda Rosa de 51 años quien tiene una pequeña pulpería y Leyla  vende ropa y cosméticos.
texts.en: The “Renovación” group has three hardworking, enterprising members.  One of them is Jenny who sells clothes.  She started this business ten years ago with some savings and then when she saw that she needed to invest more started to borrow from Adim.  She currently has three employees who sell the merchandise.  She will use the loan to buy clothes, especially seasonal items.  The other group members are Magda Rosa, 51, who has a small grocery store and Leyla who sells clothes and cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en: Saturnina is 47 years old and lives in Dimaluna, Ozamis City, Misamis Occdiental. She is married with four children. Saturnina has a shop that sells canned goods, soap ,toothpaste, noodles, etc. She has had this business for 11 years. She requested a loan to pay the school tuition fee of her son. Saturnina has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Saturnina hopes to save money for her children’s education.

loans.use: to pay the tuition fee of her son.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is married and blessed with three children all of whom attend school. 

She runs a retail shop to support her family and has been in business for the last five years.  She has stayed in business through her hard work and determination. 

Pamela has requested a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sugar, rice and wheat flour for resale. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and wheat flour for resale.

loans.name: Hauda

texts.en:
Hauda is a 55-year-old Lebanese woman. She lives on her own after getting divorced. She works to satisfy her own needs and to be capable of living life as it should be. She has owned a women's clothing shop for the past 15 years where she sells stylish, fashionable and trendy clothes, and till now she has been satisfied and looking forward to growing her business. 

Hauda is requesting a $1500 loan from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase the new winter collection such as dresses, scarves, pants, etc. She notes that this loan will certainly push her to earn higher returns. In the future, she plans to open other branches as soon as possible.

loans.use: to purchase the new winter collection such as dresses, scarves, pants, etc.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a single mother of one school-going child. She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Rehema has operated a nursery for the past six years. Her potential clients are the local students. She faces a major challenge of a delay in the payment of school fees. She dreams of establishing her primary school.

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase more desks and chairs for her classrooms. She decided to join Yehu to get capital to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more desks and chairs for her classrooms.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a farmer aged 54 and married with seven children ages between 32 and 10 years old. He has been in farming for 28 years and fully relies on the income from his current production of milk, maize, tea and vegetables sold to the local market.
Daniel has requested a loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry, so that he can venture into poultry farming too. He adds that the improvement in anticipated farming income with the new venture will help him change his family's living standards. He plans to boost his dairy business too in the future.

He notes the high cost of feed as the major challenge.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Wendtigimda Group

texts.fr:
Mme W.ADELE est la représentante du groupe WENDTIGMDA. Elle est  mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Le plus âgé a 19ans et le moins âge 02ans. 03 va  à l’école. Elle a 03 personnes  en charge.

Elle vend des fruits et légumes  depuis 10ans. Elle s’approvisionne  au  marché de pissy en ville et dans les villages environnant. Ses clients sont  le voisinage.

Elle veut  s’acheter  03 de gombo, 01 plat de levure, 10 pastèques et ¼ de sac de patate douce.

 Mme utilise ses bénéfices pour améliorer  son activité. Elle ambitionne s’acheter une parcelle, assurer  le bien être des enfants pour un meilleur avenir.
texts.en: Mrs. W. Adele is the representative of the Wendtigimda group.  She is married and the mother of 6 children.  The oldest is 19 and the youngest is 2 years old.  Three of her children go to school.  She has three people in her care.  She has sold fruits and vegetables for ten years.  She stocks up at the market in the town of Pissy and in the surrounding villages.  Her clients are her neighbors.  She wants to buy herself three okras, one dish of yeast, ten watermelons, and a quarter bag of sweet potatoes. She will use her profits to improve her business.  She hopes to buy herself a piece of land, and to ensure the well-being of her children for a better future.

loans.use: to buy herself three okras, one dish of yeast, ten watermelons, and a quarter bag of sweet potatoes.

loans.name: 030713-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lan works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase poultry and cattle to raise.

Lan is 40 years old and she is married with two children. She is the leader of a 7-member group, the 030713-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoang Hoa district, a  rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

In 2010, Lan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Lan has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Lan has been involved in this business for eight years. The main hardship that Lan faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Lan hopes to buy land of her own, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to maintain  a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase poultry and cattle to raise.

loans.name: Djidjoho Group

texts.fr: Le groupe DJIDJOHO est composé de trois personnes qui sont dans le même quartier. C'est la sixième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Romaine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Romaine est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Augustin. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Les diverses charges de la famille sont supportées par le couple. Pour cette raison, Romaine vend des bois de chauffage. Romaine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu, Romaine ensemble avec les membres du  groupe DJIDJOHO sollicite un troisième crédit. Les crédits antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des bois de chauffage.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a man with all the energy and disposition to face the world and improve himself. He is 53 years of age, very passionate, hard-working, and a dedicated farmer who hails from Nyamokenye, a remote village in the Kenyenya area of Kenya. He is committed to his wife, with whom he is blessed to have a lovely family. Like most small-scale farmers in rural Kenya, Charles has been practicing mixed farming for the past 10 years, selling milk, crops, and performing some small personal business. He has been able to earn a decent income.

Charles loves dairy farming. He is seeking a loan to purchase a dairy cow. The cow will produce 10 to 15 litres of milk every day that will be sold at the market. Money from these sales will go to loan repayment and other business expenses. Any profits from this investment will be returned to his business to propel growth. Your loan will have a great impact on Charles' life.

Charles is a believer that freedom from poverty is a basic human right and, through the loan, he will get out of the poverty bracket he is in right now. Through Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, he believes that the loan will create ripples of changes in his living conditions. Through a partnership between Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, aspiring men such as Charles are assured of achieving their dreams through loans and technical financing.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is a woman who is very dedicated to her work. Her tenacity and perseverance have allowed her to pull through, overcoming different obstacles that have arisen in her life. She is a mother of three from Ndaragwa, a remote town in the central province of Kenya. She has spent the past 10 years of her life farming. She sells eggs, milk, and vegetables produced on her farm. Of all the activities she involves herself in, poultry farming is closest to her heart.

Hannah wants to diversify and start a cereal-selling business. She is requesting a loan to buy cereals for resale. The Ndaragwa area has a ready market for cereals, but the problem is that there are no cereal suppliers. With your loan, Hannah will be able to sell cereals to the local market and to her neighbors. This will generate enough income to repay the loan, and she will also be able to save extra money. Hannah is very concerned about her children’s education, so profits from cereal selling will go to pay their school fees. She dreams of a secure future for her children.

Hannah awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy cereals for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional sewing machines and fabric for her business.

loans.name: Atik

texts.en:
Atik is 40 years old. She is a widow. She has sold bamboo straw covers for a long time, however she does not have enough bamboo, because of a shortage of capital. She has requested a $50 loan from MBK, to have more capital to buy more bamboo. The product sales are done weekly when collectors come to her house.

Translated from Indonesian by Ang, Gwan-Liong, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Expand straw hat sales business

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
Munavvar works alone to support her 3 children, parents in-law and her paralyzed husband. Her husband worked for many years at the carpet-factory in Kayrakum, and two years ago he became sick. When Munavvar is at the market, her children look after their father. Her elder daughter wants to be a lawyer.

Before, Munavvar sold food goods. Then, after receiving a loan from Microinvest, she changed her business. The spare parts she trades she brings in from Khujand. Her request for a loan is to increase her turnover, because most of her profit she now uses for medicine to her husband.

loans.use: Increase her stock of parts to trade

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Business Description

Manuel has worked in agriculture for 12 years growing rice, corn and other crops. In addition, he tends a small mango farm. He rises at 5:00AM seven days a week and returns home only when the work is done. Through his hard work, and that of his children, he has seen his crops thrive.

Use of Loan

Manuel will use this loan to care for his land and mango orchard, which have been neglected of late for lack of funds. He needs to buy fungicide, herbicide and fertilizer to keep his mango trees thriving and competitive.

Personal Information on Borrower

Manuel is 38 years old. His wife and their two children help with work on the farm. A close family, they have overcome many difficulties together and are particularly proud to have given the children a good education. Manuel hopes to boost his production of mangoes and earn a better livelihood for his family.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Don Manuel se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 12 anos, teniendo muchas otras actividades, como a la siembra de arroz, maíz y mango. Además es administrador de una pequeña finca de mango. Trabaja todos los días de la semana desde la 5 de la mañana, pero no tiene hora fija de retorno al hogar, ya que por trabajar en el campo se necesita de mucho tiempo. Gracias al esfuerzo que realiza junto con sus bellos hijos a llegado a mantener el negocio a flote, tanto en los cultivos como en la administración de la finca.

Uso del Préstamo

Manuel necesita el préstamo para reactivar sus tierras y adecuar sus sembríos de mango, ya que por falta de recursos no lo ha nutrido de la manera correcta. Comprando insumos agrícolas como, fungicidas, herbicidas y abonos, para mantenerlos a nivel de competencia, ya que por este sector se dedican mucho a la siembra de este cultivo.

Información Personal

Nuestro amigo Manuel tiene 38 anos de edad, en donde vive junto a sus 2 hermosos hijos, quienes junto a su esposa le ayudan en las actividades de la finca, son una familia unida y gracias a ello han llegado a salir de dificultades económicas y demás índoles. Gracias al esfuerzo de Manuel a llegado mantener a sus hijos estudiando, inclusive a su esposa ya que es un ejemplo de superación. Los sueños de Manuel es comercializar aun más su producto como son los mangos, de tal manera que llegue a mejorar su estilo de vida.

loans.use: To care for mango trees.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
K. Rachael is 50 years of age. She is married with three children. All the children go to school, one boy aged 15 is in senior three, and two girls aged 18 and 20 all in senior six. She has four stepchildren (two boys/two girls) who are currently in secondary school. She is operating a small hardware shop where she sells wall paint, wood vanish, wood glue, plywood, door locks and many more wares in small quantities.

Rachael would wish to get a loan of $800 to increase her stock to cater for the demand of her clients. Her business is located in the city suburbs were there are many carpentry workshops. This seemingly hard working lady is optimistic that if she adds more capital to her business it will enable her pay school fees for her children and, in future, construct rental units.

loans.use: Increasing stock

loans.name: Anani

texts.fr:
Mr. Anani D. was born in 1979 in Notsè. He is married with one child and two other children of a brother are also his dependents. He is a retailer and has a store selling cement. Because of customer demand, he would like to add other constuction materials and hardware to his inventory, but he lacks capital. He is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1000.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur D. Anani est né en 1979 à Notsè. Marié avec un enfant, et deux (02) autres enfants de son frère sont à sa charge. Il est commerçant et a un magasin de vente de ciment. Sur la demande de sa clientèle, il veut ajouter d’autres matériels de construction et la quincaillerie mais les moyens lui manquent. Il sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $1000.

loans.use:
purchase and resale of building materials and hardware

Achat et vente de matériel de construction et quincaillerie

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi O. is a 45 year old mother of 4. She comes from Mushin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells cement. She has been a LAPO member for the past 3 years and needs a loan to enable her buy more cement for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cement

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Solutions have always been part of doña Julia’s philosophy as she has always found options to solve the economic challenges of her home because she wants to see a happy and satisfied family. Therefore she decided to start a grocery store at her own house so she could be with her children. She started with few items but little by little she has increased the stock. Her children are attending school and the youngest, who is five years old, has become her companion and partner in the mornings when they tend to many customers. It is her wish to increase sales at her small store and she appeals to you for support so she can make her dream come true.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Las soluciones siempre han sido parte de la filosofía de Julia, ya que siempre ha buscado salidas rápidas para las dificultades económicas de su hogar y esto porque quiere ver a su familia muy contenta y satisfecha.Por esa razón decidió aperturar una tienda de venta de abarrotes en su misma casa, inició con poca mercadería pero poco a poco empezó a surtirla más, lo hizo para no alejarse de sus hijos. Sus hijos aún se encuentran en la escuela de su comunidad y el más pequeño tiene cinco años, él se ha convertido en su compañía y socio por las mañanas en las que atienden los pedidos de muchas personas.Tiene el deseo de incrementar las ventas de su pequeño establecimiento y recurre a vuestra ayuda a fin de obtener la cantidad que requiere para hacer de este sueño un hecho real.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to increase stock and improve sales at grocery store.

loans.name: Kyaliwajala D1B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Louinsa K.. She is currently in the business of matooke (green banana) selling and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Louinsa is 40 years old and is married and her husband is a driver. She has 6 children ranging from age 15 to 23 and her children go to school. Each week, Louinsa makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save for her children's education. Louinsa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest it in the matooke business and the loan was paid back on time.

Louinsa is joined in her small group by Milly N., Mable Nakuwadde, Jane A., and Jane K.. Milly N. is currently in the business of tomato selling and is requesting a loan to increase stock. Mable Nakuwadde is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to construct a kibanda (shade) for the charcoal. Jane A. is currently in the business of selling local brew and is requesting a loan to expand her brew business. Jane K. currently operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add stock in the shop.

loans.use: To purchase various types of raw foods thus expand business

loans.name: Santigie

texts.en: Santigie sells second hand clothes in Makeni town of Sierra Leone.  He is 38 years old and is a school drop out who needs to earn income to support his parents.  With previous loans from SMT, he rented a space in the open market to run his business. The business is the main source of income for the family.  He is, therefore, requesting a loan to expand the business and, in the future, rent a better space.  Santigie is married with a child.

loans.use: Santigie is faced with supporting many dependants and needs to supplement his business enough so that it can produce the profits needed.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy is a very affectionate and responsible granddaughter. Since childhood, she has always sought ways to earn her own income and to contribute to the cost of running her family’s humble home. She is currently pursuing her higher education and to pay her own way, she decided to engage in various business activities such as selling cosmetics and beauty products, cellular phones, children’s overcoats, and woollen ponchos, that in many cases she weaves herself with great patience and creativity. With all these activities she is achieving her aims and above all she provides peace and well being to her grandparents who always supported and looked after her.

Nancy’s desire is to have more capital to invest in her business selling cosmetics and beauty products; a desire that relies on the goodness of your heart.

Translated from Spanish by MuseAndThinker, Kiva Volunteer

Nancy, es una nieta muy cariñosa y responsable, desde pequeña siempre ha buscado la manera de generar sus propios ingresos económicos y aportar con los gastos de su humilde hogar, actualmente viene cursando estudios superiores y para cubrir sus gastos decidió dedicarse a diversas actividades tales como: la venta de cosméticos de belleza, celulares, abrigos para niños y ponchos de lana que en muchos casos los teje personalmente con suma paciencia y creatividad.Con estas labores está logrando su propósito y sobre todo está brindándoles tranquilidad y bienestar a sus queridos abuelitos quienes son las personas que siempre la apoyaron y velaron por ella.El deseo de Nancy es contar con mayor capital para invertir en su negocio venta de cosméticos de belleza, con ese plan recurre a tu solidario corazón.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase stock and to offer a greater variety of beauty products

loans.name: Zuena

texts.en:
Zuena is 25 years old, married with a 2-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of one other 2- year-old child. In 2005, Zuena began seling charcoal seller, and everyday she works from 8am to 4pm at her business. She can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Aubjon

texts.en: K. Aubjon lives in Khujand. Mr. K. Aubjon has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002. He showed himself to be a reliable client who follows the MicroInvest loan procedure. Now, he applies for a business development loan for 8 months. Mr. K. Aubjon is engaged in commercial service and trade. He has a business in food selling (milk products, meat products, sugar, etc…). He has a trade outlet and a good assortment of products. Mr.K. Aubjon wants to widen the assortment of products that he sells. Mr. K. Aubjon thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To widen the existing assortment

loans.name: Babalola

texts.en:
A. Babalola is 34 years old and married with 4 children. She sells rice to neighboring markets and other small entrepreneurs in her community. She learned this business for 4 years and opened her own shop 12 years ago. 
Babalola needs a loan of US$1,200 to buy more bags of rice so that she can meet the demands of her numerous customers.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Neema John's Red Rose Group

texts.en:
Neema J., age 38, is single and has two children (ages 10 and 2 1/2). She sells food from 8 AM to 4 PM daily and earns a profit of about $431 a month.

In the past, Neema repaid two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she used to increase her business. She is requesting a new loan to pay her daughter's school fees and purchase more cereals to sell. She will share this loan with the seven other members of her Red Rose group. These members hold each other accountable for repaying their loans.

In the picture, Neema is the second person from the left in the orange dress.

loans.use: Pay school fees for her daughter and to increase stock of cereals to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort O. is 50 years old and married with 4 children. She is a LAPO client. Comfort sells fruit like bananas, apples, and mangoes. She started selling fruit in 2008.

Comfort lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos state, Nigeria. She needs a loan of $425 to buy more fruit for sale. She says this will enable her to meet the demands of her customers. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more fruit like bananas, apples, and mangoes to sell.

loans.name: Miriam Del Rosario

texts.es: Inició su pequeño negocio vendiendo golosinas y refrescos naturales en el corredor de su casa hace cinco años y aprovechando la oportunidad de tener un primer  crédito con ADIM de $100.00 compró más golosinas y ofreció comidas rápidas, desayunos, almuerzos y cenas. Actualmente vive con dos hijas y su esposo, sus hijas estudian y tiene el apoyo de su esposo que trabaja en un taller de pintura; tiene su propia caseta donde vende y tiene mejores condiciones que en el corredor y los clientes son mejor atendidos. Actualmente con el préstamo ella compró sillas y mesas para brindar una mejor atención a sus clientes.
texts.en:
She began her small business selling snacks and natural beverages in the corridor of her home five years ago. Taking advantage of the opportunity to have her first loan with ADIM for US$100, she bought more snacks and offered fast food, breakfasts, lunches, and dinners. Today she lives with her two daughters and husband; her daughters study and she has the support of her husband who working in a paint shop. She has her own stand where she sells and she has better conditions that the corridor and her customers are better served. Today with the loan she will buy chairs and tables to provide better service to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make food

loans.name: Blanca Ludivina

texts.es:
Blanca inicio hace 5 años su negocio porque tenia que comprar calzado para sus hijos y se le hacia muy difícil comprarlo de contado ya que es muy caro así que decidió dedicarse a vender zapatos por catalogo, inicio ofreciéndolo sus vecinas y así se fue haciendo de clientes, ya que como tiene 4 hijos es difícil mantenerse con el sueldo de su marido el cual es muy variable ya que es comerciante en los mercados rodantes y en ocasiones por las lluvias o inclemencias del tiempo no le va bien con el negocio por lo cual decidió apoyarlo y para no descuidar a su hijo eligió el ramo de los zapatos en el cual le ha ido muy bien.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $400 que pagara en 6 meses para invertir y tener mejores ventas. Con tu apoyo esto será posible.
texts.en:
Blanca started her business 5 years ago after she had to buy shoes for her children and found it difficult to buy them with cash because of the expense. That gave her the idea to buy shoes from catalogs and resell them. She started by offering her products to her neighbors who became her first customers. It's hard to support 4 children on her husband's income because he works as a merchant selling products in the region's temporary markets and his income is variable because of frequent bad weather. That's why Blanca decided to help her husband. In order not to disappoint her son she chose shoe sales, a business that has gone very well.

Blanca needs a US$400 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, to invest and increase sales. With your support, this will be possible.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. is a 38-year-old married woman with three children, all of whom are currently in school. She is a busy petty trader who has been selling maize grain, plantains, cassava, and other foodstuffs on a table at the local market for the past eight years. More specifically, she has been trading in the market of Tema in the Greater Accra Region of Ghana, where she resides with her family.

Unfortunately, she does not have sufficient working capital to properly run her business, thereby retarding the business' progress. As such, she is seeking a loan to inject more working capital into the business so that she can purchase additional inventory to revive the business. In turn, she believes that the loan proceeds will enable her to increase her savings in order to support her kids in school.

Grace belongs to the group known as the Morning Star Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee each other's loans as social collateral (i.e., if one member does not promptly repay her portion of the loan, then the other members are responsible for curing the arrears), and they provide support for one another to repay their respective loans. She notes that she does not sell any goods on group meeting days, and that her picture was taken during her group meeting. She is very grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To revive her business by expanding her inventory (e.g., stocks of cassava, fresh tomatoes, onions, beans, maize, and dried fish)

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Mrs. Chem S., 40, is married and lives with her husband and their two school-aged children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works in a grocery store, making about $5 a day, while her husband is a tailor.

Mrs. Chem S. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to add items to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.use: To add to her grocery’s inventory.

loans.name: Konstantin

texts.en:
Konstantin is divorced. He lives in Kherson, in the southern part of Ukraine. Konstantin sells bikes and accessories in the local Dneprovskyi market. He offers a good assortment of inventory and the quality of all his stock is always the best. Konstantin has been in this business for 6 years. He has about 21,000 Grivnas invested in his business. His monthly income is about 5,000 Grivnas.

Konstantin is very disciplined, responsible, and accurate in every activity he takes on. He likes healthy competition but would never envy the success of his fellow businessmen who work in the same sphere of business. His competitors talk about him as a competent, respectful, and balanced entrepreneur. Konstantin is seeking a 5,000 Grivna loan to purchase additional merchandise for his vending kiosk, expecting to increase his income as a result.

loans.use: purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Ajab Khan

texts.en: Ajab Khan is the son of A. A.. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a general store where he sells different kinds of things and supports all his family members with the income. He would like to expand his business and buy some more inventory for his shop to attract more customers. He wants to take an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani for a term of 12 months to buy all the required materials to have a well-stocked shop.

loans.use: purchasing new inventory

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf femmes du groupe SINIGNESSIGUI sont toutes mariées avec en moyenne  26 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans les familles conjugales traditionnelles dans le village de ZANFINA, sous préfecture de KONOBOUGOU, dans la préfecture de BAROUELI région de SEGOU république du Mali. 
Unies par des relations commerciales, ces femmes  font généralement  la même activité à savoir  le commerce du bois de chauffe. 
Afin d’améliorer leur activité elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de   l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe. Les précédents prêts ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, 15 tonnes de bois de chauffe avec les charretiers de WEREKELA qui vont couper du bois de chauffe dans la forêt du dit village. Ces bois sont ensuite vendus dans la ville de Fana  au comptant en détail et à crédit  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Ces femmes comptent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour étoffer leur fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
The nine women of the group SINIGNESSIGUI are all married and average 26 years of age and 4 children. They live for the most part in traditional conjugal families in the village of ZANFINA (in KONOBOUGOU sub-prefecture, part of BAROUELI prefecture) in the SEGOU region, Republic of Mali. United by commercial ties, these women generally work in the same field, namely commerce in firewood.

In order to improve their business, they decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are on their third group loan. The preceding ones have been repaid

The group members plan to use this loan to buy 15 tonnes of firewood with the cart drivers of WEREKELA who are going to chop some firewood in the forest of the aforementioned village. This wood is then sold retail in the city of Fana, cash or credit accepted, to customers composed of men and women.

With this loan, the group members intend to realize a profit of 30,000 francs CFA that will be used to increase their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: John

texts.es: John tiene 32 años, vive con sus 2 hijos en casa de sus padres. Se dedica al transporte en motocarro desde hace 3 años, cubriendo la ruta interna de su localidad, trabaja diariamente y durante todo el día ofreciendo este servicio. John disfruta de su trabajo porque es independiente y dueño de su propia movilidad, además se puede dar un tiempo libre para sus hijos. Este trabajo le permite cubrir sus gastos y las necesidades de sus hijos, por lo que considera que esta actividad tiene buenas ganancias y le anima a planificar su futuro comprando otras unidades para hacerlas trabajar con otros choferes. Es la primera vez que viene solicitando un préstamo con MFP, para él, esta es una nueva experiencia de trabajo en común con varias personas, lo que es de su agrado y se compromete a seguir adelante. La cantidad que requiere es para la compra de llantas nuevas para su movilidad, además del pago de la renovación del seguro de accidentes.
texts.en:
John is 32 years old, and he lives with his two children in his parents' house. He has been working with an autorickshaw for three years, covering an internal route in his town. He works all day every day offering his service. John enjoys his work because he is independent and has his own mobility, and he can take some time off for his kids. This job allows him to cover his expenses and the needs of his children, therefore he believes that this activity has good profits and that encourages him to plan his future buying other units to make them work with other drivers. This is the first time he has requested a loan with MFP. For him, this is a new work experience in common with other people, which he likes and he is commited to keep going forward. The amount he requests is for the purchase of new tires for his unit, plus the renovation of his accident insurance.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new tires for his autorickshaw and insurance

loans.name: Luz Elminda

texts.es:
La señora  Luz Elminda pertenece al Banco Comunal  “PEQUEÑAS EMPRESARIAS II”, vive en el Pasaje San Jorge Nº 28  Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es  separada de su esposo  tiene dos hijas a su cargo.

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, empezó vendiendo plastiquerìa ( artículos de plásticos como baldes, jarras, platos, tazones) en los pueblos cercanos  de Tarapoto. Tiene 02 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal.

En la actualidad se dedica a la Venta de ollas artesanales elaboradas a base de arcilla, como también ropa interior y polos  para damas y caballeros. Sus principales clientes son los  moradores de la comunidad  de Lamas, Cacatachi lugares cercanos a la capital de la provincia.

Con este préstamo de S/  1,000.00 que cancelara en un plazo de 06 meses, lo invertirá, comprando al por mayor 24 cocinas artesanales, ropas de niños y caballeros  que son pedidos de sus clientes. 

Ella mayormente toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, desea ampliar más su negocio y construir cuartos para alquiler  y se  siente más segura con el pago de sus cuotas. 

Luz Elminda manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Luz Elminda is a member of the Communal Bank "Little Businesswomen II" and lives on San Jorge Street in the District of Tarapoto, Department of San Martín. She is separated from her spouse and has two children in her care. With her first loan of $100, she began selling plastics (including buckets, jars, plates, and bowls) in the towns near Tarapoto. She has been working with the Communal Bank for two years. She currently works selling artisanal pots created with clay, as well as underwear and polo shirts for men and women. Her principal clients are residents within communities near the capital of Lamas and Cacatachi. With a loan of $325 to be repaid in 6 months, she will invest in the wholesale purchase of 24 artisanal cookers as well as children's and men's clothing per her clients' requests. She makes the majority of the decisions regarding her business and its earnings. Luz Elminda's personal goals are to: build her business, construct rooms to rent, and feel more confident in her ability to make her loan payments. Luz Elminda expresses her thanks to Kiva partner Manuel Ramos for allowing her the opportunity to grow as a businesswoman and as a person.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of artisanal cookers and children's and men's clothing.

loans.name: Susan's Group

texts.en:
Susan is a 23-year-old single woman. She supports her parents with her clothing shop. Susan has been running her clothing shop alone for 1.5 years. She says that people prefer her shop over other shops because she talks to her customers very nicely.

Susan is requesting a loan of 1.1 million USH. She will use this loan to pay an installment on her rent. Each month Susan must pay 700,000 USH in rent on her shop. She will also purchase some stock for her store. With her loan she will be able to buy 5 dozen dresses, 2 dozen trousers, and 2 dozen tops.

Susan dreams of some day being able to sell 10 dozen items per day. She says that if she is able to do this it will help her achieve her dream of buying a house and a car.

loans.use: To purchase 5 dozen dresses, 2 dozen trousers, 2 dozen tops, and pay some rent.

loans.name: Abuali

texts.ru: Калонов Абуали житель города Турсун-заде. Возраст33 года, женат и имеет одного ребенка. Всю жизнь обеспечивает семью путем разведения крупно рогатого скота. Покупает скот для откормки и перепродает на рынках. Обратился к нам за кредитом для того , чтобы увеличить поголовье скота. Таким образом он сможет улучшить свое финансовое положение , а так же обеспечить рынки качественным мясом.
texts.en:
K. Abuali lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 33 years old, is married and has one child. For his entire life he has provided for his family by raising livestock. He purchases livestock to fatten it and resells it at the markets. He turned to us for a loan in order to increase his livestock headcount. This way he will be able to improve his financial situation and to provide the markets with quality meat.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a bull

loans.name: Las Lunitas Group

texts.es:
En la foto tenemos al  Banco Comunal  “Las Lunitas”  este  es el primer ciclo de este Banco Comunal, la mayoría vive en Jr. calleria, Distrito de Yarinacocha y quien la representa es la Sra. T. C. Loyda Lilly con 34 años de edad ella vende ropa y   vive  en el Distrito de Yarinacocha en el Jr. callaría Mz 157-A Lt. 07. 

       El Banco Comunal esta conformado por 11 socias, ellas confían mucho entre ellas y tienen muchas ganas de hacer crecer sus negocios.  Con este préstamo de S/. 3,300 nuevos soles, comprarán ropa , abarrotes, bebidas heladas, plátano y otros con los que podrán hacer crecer mucho mas sus negocios.

  	Ellas  están muy satisfechas por haber ingresado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos - CrediMujer, ya que gracias a ello podrán contar con un capital propio, para darles mejor educación y alimentación a sus familias.
texts.en:
Banco Comunal “Las Lunitas” is in the photo. This is the first loan request from this group. Most of the group members live on Calleria Street, Yarinacocha District. Mrs. T. C. Loyda Lilly, 34 years old, is the leader. She sells clothing and lives at Mz 157-A Lt.07 Calleria Street, Yarinacocha District. This group is composed of 11 members. They confide in each other and wish to expand their businesses. With this loan of $1,100, they will buy clothing, vegetables, cold drinks, bananas and other items that will help their businesses to grow. They are very glad they joined the Movimiento Manuela Ramos - CrediMujer and are grateful they will be able to obtain capital in order to improve their education and feed their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes, vegetables, drinks, fruits.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.es:
Rosalina es socia del Banco Comunal Las Gaviotas.
Rosalina es separada, tiene 45 años y 6 hijos, Rosalina vende emoliente (bebida caliente preparada con semillas de lino y hierbas, que tiene propiedades curativas) actividad que realiza por las noches de manera ambulatoria. Además Rosalina teje chompas de acuerdo a pedidos.
Rosalina necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de lana, cebada y linaza.
Los sueños de Rosalina son construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Rosalina is a member of the Village Bank The Seagulls. Rosalina is seperated, is 45 years old and has six children. Rosalina sells emollient (a hot drink prepared with flax seeds and herbs, that has curative properties) an activity carried out at night on an outpatient basis. Further, Rosalina knits sweaters as requested. Rosalina need an 800 soles loan that will be invested in the purchase of wool, barley and flaxseed. Rosalina's dream is to build a home and to provide a good education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Hopkins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wool, barley and flaxseed.

loans.name: Nisida

texts.es:
La señora Nisida, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Emprendedoras”, Distrito de Moyobamba, Provincia Moyobamba, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 22 años, y un 01 hijo pequeño.

Su espíritu  alegre y su anhelo de sacar adelante a su hijo, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes con cuyas ganancias ayudaría al ingreso económico de su familia, desde su  inicio a la fecha ha ido ganando clientes. En la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su bodega ubicada en el Mercado “Los Ángeles” – Moyobamba a comprar porque en su negocio encuentran todos los productos  que el ama de casa necesita y es quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00,  comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, huevos en javas y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Nisida, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando, y perseverando día a día y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Nisida belongs to the Mujeres Emprendedoras Community Bank in the Moyobamba district, Moyobamba province, San Martín department. She is 22, in a common law marriage, and has a small son. Her happy spirit and her desire to help her son’s future motivated her to start her own business selling groceries. She would use her earnings to help her family. From the beginning she has been steadily gaining customers. She currently has fixed customers who come to her store, which is located in the Los Ángeles market in Moyabamba. They come every day to buy because they find everything a housewife needs. She personally waits on them with her characteristic charisma. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packages of noodles, milk, boxes of various brands of canned fish, eggs, and personal hygiene products to continue giving good attention to her customers. Nisida feels that she has a lot of strength to keep working and persevering day to day. She is thankful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her have opportunities to develop in the midst of where they can blossom.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries to increase her stock

loans.name: Martina

texts.en: Martina O. is a seamstress in Kotokoraba in Cape Coast. She also sells sewing materials. Martina has received a vocational education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a trader. Martina has been sewing and selling sewing materials since 1998. She is responsible for paying school fees. Her loan will be used to buy sewing materials to sell. She hopes to reinvest her new profits in her business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy sewing materials to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace A. sells provisions such as canned fish, baked beans, and cocoa beverages in Hohoe. She has received primary education. She is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a trader.

Grace has been selling provisions since 1991. She helps her husband in paying the housekeeping expenses and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for resale. She hopes to reinvest the profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for her grocery store

loans.name: Prosperidad Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su decimo  ciclo es un comité ejemplar. Las integrantes de este comité realizan distintos tipos de actividades comerciales en las que invierten el dinero de crédito con el fin de que el negocio vaya creciendo y aumentando sus ganancias. Estas actividades son:
1	Zunilda C. 	Manicurista
2	Lizza P.	Venta de Bebidas
3	Eva S.	Venta de Biyouteri
4	Blanca R.	Venta de comidas
5	Josefina G.	Venta de cd y películas
6	Liliana F.	Manicurista 
7	Eulalia C.	Venta de mercería
8	Francisca R.	Venta de lenceria
9	Gabriela V.	Venta de Lenceria
10	Lucia G.	Venta de golosinas
11	Gloria A.	Venta de cosmeticos
12	Mariana R.	Venta de ropas
13	Diana G.	Venta de comestibles
14	Clarise V.	Venta de mercerias|
15	Antonia A.	Costurera
16	Gladis N.	Venta de Articulos de limpieza
17	Jenny A.	 Venta de comestibles

Podemos hablar de la Sra. Zunilda C. de 40 años , tiene 3 hijos que dos de sus hijos pequeños se quedan en una guarderia  y los otros tres se quedan en la en la casa mientras la madre se va a trabajar haciendo sus manicuras y pedicuros en la zona de  Viñas Cue y los fines de semana se dedica a hacer  actividades con sus compañeras del comité para  crear una entrada más en sus ahorros como  por ejemplo hacen ferias y venta de hamburguesas. 
Ella es una señora muy  dedicada a sus hijos que hace de todo tipo de trabajo para ayudar a su pareja en los gastos de la familia.  
Tiene una casita  pequeña hecha de materiales  vive cerca de un desagüe que les hace pasar malos momentos y que piensa comprarse otra casita para su estabilidad y la de su familia.

loans.use: Compra de mercaderías varias para la venta como frutas, verduras, carne, aceite, azúcar, lenceria, ropas, cd´s, golosinas, gaseosas, bijouterie,etc.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
Felipa tiene 34 años, vive con su esposo, Dilmer, y sus hijos: Verónica de 26, Jonathan de 23, Jacky de 22 en su casa propia. Desde hace un año se dedica al comercio por temporada, actualmente está vendiendo bolsas plásticas, lo cual le es muy rentable porque se contacta con las empresas que realizan estas bolsas al por mayor, entonces ella compra grandes cantidades y las vende en los diferentes mercados de la ciudad. Felipa quiere vender cada vez más, para que con las ganancias pueda tener un negocio más estable, lo ha pensado mucho y se ha decidido por implementar una bodega en su vivienda, es por ello que está ahorrando para lograr su objetivo, ya que le resultaría mucho más cómodo y beneficioso para su economía.
Este es su cuarto préstamo con MFP, siempre ha sido muy puntual en sus pagos, ya que su grupo es muy exigente y responsable a la hora de cumplir con las cuotas. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará bolsas y también algunos productos para ir abasteciendo su tienda, la cual espera abrir muy pronto.
texts.en:
Felipa is 34 years old, and lives with her husband Dilmer and their children: Verónica (26), Jonathan (23), and Jacky (22) in their own home. For a year she has had a seasonal business selling plastic bags, which is very profitable because she contacts the firms that sell these bags wholesale, then purchases large quantities and sells them in different markets in the city. Felipa would like to sell more and more, so that the earnings could make her business more stable. She has thought about it a lot and has decided to put a store in her house, and for this reason she is saving to achieve this objective, given that this would be more convenient and beneficial for her economic wellbeing. This is her fourth loan with MFP, she has always been very punctual in her payments, since her group is very successful and responsible and makes its payments on time. With the money that she requests now she will buy bags and also some products in order to supply her store, which she hopes to open very soon.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to increase merchandise and invest in a new business

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en:
Celerina A. is from the village of Sepac. She is 58 years old. Celerina is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Celerina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Celerina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Celerina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celerina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Celerina is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be Celerina's twelfth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for hog raising

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
This is Antonina G., 42, a seasoned fruit dealer from Dasmarinas, Cavite. She lives with her husband, Alfredo, 48, a driver, and their six children in a middle-class house at a government subsidized relocation site.

Antonina has been selling bananas in wholesale and retail. She renovated part of her house to be a store room as well as selling area. She employs five neighbors working as porters and assistants attending to customers and farmers/merchants frequenting her house.  She earns more than PHP 35,000 a month.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006, but has been enjoying its many social benefits for community members. Antonina is applying for a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of PHP 25,000 as additional capital for her banana business.
 
Antonina dreams of having her own car that she can use to buy fruit from farmers and deliver that fruit to other merchants.



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her banana vending business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and sell used clothing

loans.name: Tsegmid

texts.en:
Tsegmid T. is 22 years old and lives with her mother and two-year-old daughter in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. With her mother's help, she operates a grocery and firewood business at a small shop in her town.

T. started her business in 2006 with capital of 200,000 MNT. She has made much progress in her first three years of operation and has built a stable business. Her earnings have enabled her to provide for her mother and daughter and improve their quality of life. Today, her working capital exceeds 500,000 MNT. T. hopes to continue to grow her business in the future and provide her daughter with a good life. She is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase grocery products and coal to sell.

About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products and coal to sell

loans.name: Luz Angelica

texts.es:
La señora Luz Angélica, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Dorcas de San Juan”, Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 35 años y no tiene hijos.

Luz Angélica, es una mujer que ha podido superar muchas dificultades en su camino de vida, se siente muy contenta y orgullosa por lo logrado. Luz Angélica, poco a poco fue ahorrando y generando su propio capital, así de esta manera se inicio con la venta de cosméticos, nos cuenta que hoy en día le esta yendo muy bien.

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,100.00, comprará productos de belleza para su aumentar su stock como: perfumes y colonias para damas, caballeros y niños; cremas, polvos compactos, lápices labiales, esmaltes de uñas.

Luz Angélica, es un ejemplo a seguir de muchas mujeres que se inician en un negocio y con perseverancia logran alcanzar sus sueños. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por ayudarla a iniciar su propio negocio y a otras mujeres a crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Ms. Luz Angelica A. is a member of the Las Dorcas de San Juan Communal Bank in the la Banda de Shilcayo district of the San Martin province and department. She is a 35-year-old woman with a live-in partner and no children.

Luz Angelica is a woman who has been able to overcome many difficulties along the path of her life. She feels very satisfied with everything that she has accomplished. She managed to save up her money little by little, generating her own capital, which was how she launched her cosmetics business. She states that her business is prospering nowadays.

With this 1,100.00 PEN loan, she will purchase beauty products like fragrances for men, women, and children; cold cream, compact powder, lipsticks, and nail polish.

Luz Angelica is an example for many female small business owners; with perseverance, they shall realize their dreams. She is very grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her launch her own business and for helping other women grow as entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products

loans.name: Sarita Colonia Group

texts.es:
LA SRA.ISIDORA A. S., TIENE 47 AÑOS DE EDAD,ES CASADA Y TIENE DOS HIJOS, QUE SON SU RAZÓN DE TODO SACRIFICIO Y ESFUERZO. ELLA INTEGRA HACE 4 AÑOS,EL GRUPO "SARITA COLONIA",DONDE DESEMPEÑA EL CARGO DE PRESIDENTA.
LA SRA. ISIDORA,HACE DIEZ AÑOS SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE ABARROTES, EN UN ESPACIO DE SU CASA, DONDE ADMINISTRA SU BODEGA. ELLA INICIÓ CON LA VENTA DE CERVEZAS Y GASEOSAS, DONDE LAAPOYÓ SU ESPOSO YA QUE EL CAPITAL INICIAL FUÉ TOMADO DE UNA PARTE DE SU SUELDO.
CON EL TRABAJO EN SU BODEGA , HA PODIDO APOYAR ECONÓMICAMENTE A SU HIJO EN SUS ESTUDIOS SUPERIORES, EMPEZÓ A CONSTRUIR SU CASITA Y COMPRÓ OTRO TERRENO.
ELPRESTAMO SOLICITADO LO UTILIZARÁ PARA INVERTIR EN SU MERCADERÍA PARA SU NEGOCIO.
texts.en:
Isidora A. S. is 47, married and has two children, who are the reason for all her efforts and sacrifice. She is the president of the "Sarita Colonia" Group, of which she has been a member for the past four years. For ten years she has been selling groceries from a grocery store in her house. She started out selling beer and sodas with the support of her husband, who used part of his salary as start-up capital. Income from the grocery store has allowed Isidora to support her son's higher education, start building her house, and buy another lot. She plans to invest this loan in merchandise for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her grocery store

loans.name: Liz Danisa

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Liz Danisa tiene 31 años, es madre soltera y tiene tres hijos y es padre y madre de sus tres hijos: Liz Magaly tiene 11 años, Tania tiene 4 años y Alex tiene 3 años. La socia Liz Danisa es natural de la ciudad de Urubamba departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “JOSE CARLOS MARIATEGUI” de la Asociación Arariwa. 

La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y almuerzo para sus hijos. La socia después de hacer sus actividades del hogar tiene que ir a las 7 de la mañana al “Mercado de Señor de Torrechayoc” a vender “Ojotas” (Estas ojotas o sandalias de goma, se construyen a partir de neumáticos usados que han sido cortados en forma o incluso tejida con tiras finas y se ven en los mercados en las pequeñas ciudades a través de América del Sur.). La socia nos cuenta que estas ojotas lo adquieren campesinos y pobladores de bajos recursos pues sus costos son muy bajos en comparación a los zapatos normales. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido buen bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más ojotas y los adquiere en la ciudad del Cusco. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. 

La ciudad de Urubamba se encuentra a 78 Km. de la Ciudad del Cusco aproximadamente a una hora y media de viaje. La ciudad de Urubamba se halla en el corazón del Valle Sagrado. En la época prehispánica fue un centro agrícola muy importante
texts.en:
Liz Danisa is 31 years old and a single mother. Therefore, she has to be both father and mother to her three children: Liz Magaly (age 11), Tania (age 4), and Alex (age 3). Liz Danisa is a native of the city of Urubamba in the Department of Cusco. She is a member of the Jose Carlos Mariategui Communal Bank, which is part of Asociación Arariwa.

Liz Danisa wakes up early to perform her household activities, such as preparing breakfast and lunch for her children. Afterwards, she heads toward the “Señor de Torrechayoc” Market where she sells “ojotas” (flip-flops made of used tires that have been cut up and woven into thin strips). The material used to make this type of footwear is found in small-town markets across South America. Liz Danisa says she acquires her merchandise from peasants and low-income residents because the cost is much lower in comparison to normal shoes. She has been in this line of business for several years and has done well because of the effort she puts into her work. Her loan will be used to buy more flip-flops from Cusco.

Liz Danisa is grateful for this opportunity and promises to make her payments on time.

The city of Urubamba is located 78 km away from Cusco, which is a 90 minute trip. It is located in the heart of the Sacred Valley. In Pre-Hispanic times, Urubamba was an important agricultural center.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flip-flops to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam M. is 38 years old and a widow. She has five school-aged children. Mariam is currently running a shop where she sells medicines, and is requesting a loan to stock more drugs to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more drugs to sell

loans.name: Force To Go #1 Group

texts.en:
Gabriel G. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Force to Go #1. He is 35 years old, single, and has four children who are 2, 9, 11 and 14 years old. The oldest child is in 7th grade, and the youngest is in 1st grade. Gabriel himself was only able to complete school through the 10th grade.

Gabriel owns a footwear business in the Waterside market, which is the largest market in Monrovia. He has had this business for four years, and he attracts customers by selling quality goods in a friendly manner.

Gabriel plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more footwear. He hopes that one day he will be so successful that he will be able to open his own footwear store. Most importantly, he wants to be able to feed his children and see them get a good education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Gabriel is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more footwear.

loans.name: Comite Cerrito Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Cerrito, se conformo en fecha 24 de marzo del 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Antoliana Fernández, quien se dedica a la Venta. de artesanías, contactó con la asesora que también tenía un grupo en la misma zona, se informó del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y una vez asesorada acerca del ProgramaEl Comité de Mujeres de nombre Cerrito, se conformo en fecha 24 de marzo del 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General la Sra. Antoliana Fernández, quien se dedica a la Venta. de artesanías, contactó con la asesora que también tenía un grupo en la misma zona, se informó del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y una vez  que la asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 15 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 6º ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
 Es un excelente grupo gracias al  trabajo solidario realizado y continuan trabajando con el programa hasta estos días.
El préstamo lo  destinan para diferentes actividades tales como venta de comidas, venta de mercerías, compra de mercaderías,venta de artículos de librería, venta de bebidas, venta de gallinas,venta de frutas y verduras, venta de quiniela, venta de escobas, venta de ropas, ect.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.

texts.en:
The Cerrito Women’s Committee was formed on March 24th, 2008, thanks to the current general director, Antoliana Fernández, who sells handicrafts. She contacted the advisor, who had a group in the same area. She inquired about the Committee of Enterprising Women’s Program. Once she was informed about the Program, she was able to get 15 women together. They are now comfortably working together as a supportive team during the sixth cycle of the program. It is an excellent group thanks to the supportive work they do, and they currently continue working in the program. The loan is for their different businesses like selling food, selling sewing supplies, buying merchandise, selling bookstore items, selling drinks, selling chickens, selling fruits and vegetables, selling sports lottery tickets, selling brooms, and selling clothes, etc. All of them run their businesses to raise funds. They help each other reach the common objectives that they all have within the group and with the Paraguaya Foundation. They actively participate in weekly meetings and have formed an impeccable collective effort. 1 Antoliana Fernández Sells handicrafts 2 Cantalicia Q. Sells Avon products 3 Liduvina Colmán Sells food 4 Ma.Zunilda G. Sells brooms 5 Brigida S. Sells food 6 Rumilda Vázquez Sells clothes 7 Ladislaa P. Sells sports lottery tickets 8 Sadi S. Book store

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy thread and fabric

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie H. is from the village of Sibugon Lopez Jaena Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Tessie is married and has 5 grown children. To make a living, Tessie owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies like rice cakes "puto" to the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Tessie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer for the rice farm. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Tessie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for the rice farm

loans.name: Hizar

texts.en:
Hizar is a 23-year-old married woman and mother of one young child. In order to help with her family’s expenses, Hizar has opened a small teaching business from her home; she started receiving the village children who needs education supports since 2007 at her home where she has prepared a special room for this purpose. She' very happy with her business because she's able to help the children and she feels that it's a mission in her life. 

Today, Hizar is requesting to borrow $700 to build a new education room with all the preparation related such as stationary, new chairs and tables, board etc. because she's planning to receive more students and expand her business. And she hopes that her family status level will be also developed as a result of the loan.
